PGood is polled periodically, may not represent current state. Is that a problem? Can you provide more info about the use case?
Is there a review for this change?
in case, if oem specific IPMB command format varies,then this enum type class can be used to load the IPMB commands.
struct with names would be easier to understand and maintain

It is taken as reference from the IPMBsensor to keep the code implementation similar.
Is it okay keep it or make it struct with names?
Ack. Maybe later can be improved for IPMBsensor in a separate patch
seems like the two variables are the same, can just use one
Is there a catch somewhere? Or should it crash the service?
variable name does not make sense
It will be initialized from json file
what if they are not specified?
If EntityId and Index empty GPIO sensor creation is skipped.
Is there a better name for it. I am not sure we want use platform name in variable names.
This header file doesn't need, if below comment is addressed.
There is already a function which does this operation. Please refer that. https://github.com/openbmc/dbus-sensors/blob/master/include/Utils.hpp#L45
do we still want wait when initialize fails?
class and type has a one to one mapping, I don't understand why both are needed

For differnt platform, multiple types also be added in future
keeping this type as place holder
If this variable is not modified, then reference by address doesn't need here.
move it before use, i.e. when line 497 is true

I don't understand the interaction with x86-power-control described here.

When x86-power-control receives power ON
if (PGood == true), x86-power-control power ON host
else (PGood == false), x86-power-control power OFF host

Please correct me if I misunderstood anything.

So power ON request could actually result in host to be powered OFF?
This is still confusing to me.

The intension here is to simulate the behaviour of monitoring pgood gpio state which is required to proceed further in the host power on process only here gpio pgood state value is read via dbus-property.
every things else is similar based on the x86-power-control state events.

I am bit confused here: why Gpio is mentioned used in naming things. Is this because the OEM command is reading Gpio status?
To me this is reading host PGood through IPMB commands.
In this case the pgood state is Gpio which is accessed via IPMB commands.

In entity-manager, this config files work based on the twinlake ipmb fru(using probe). 

Instance has been populated form the ipmb fru devices. a specific oem netfun and command has used in the GpioStateSensor.
More information can be found by reading the documentation for EM config files, as well as the overall themes.  If you have questions, please ask them.

The previous comment is already address 
(TwinlakeHostController is used in generic as HostController)
but the current patchsets still mention GPIO, so how has this been resolved?
In the latest patch, it will be resolved.
Should this be count as error?
why negative logic? if (pgoodGpioByte >= ipmbGpiuoData.size()) is easier to read
nit: add "continue" after this, the else clause below is not needed. Rest of code in the function can keep the same, including format.
shall we keep its as else clause since it helps in readabilty.

Hai all,
Gentle remainder, Please review on this patch if possible.

Need skip line 141-143
Also, should it be counted as error?
Rearrange the code so that diff is readable for the reviewer.

The reason it is clubbed together with ipmb sensor  is that this gpio sensor is kind of ipmb  sensor where we read the gpio state via ipmb. Also  it needs to be instantiated from the createsensors function.
Apart from the object creation, all other logics are move under seperate class.
Hai @Ed Tanuos,
Do we need to create a seperate main function and createsensor function for this gpio state via ipmb?
please suggest your opinion on this.

> The reason it is clubbed together with ipmb sensor  is that this gpio sensor is kind of ipmb  sensor where we read the gpio state via ipmb.

Then it should use the same internals.  It shouldn't need to host the same object.

> Also  it needs to be instantiated from the createsensors function.

This doesn't mean that you're not required to abstract out your functionality appropriately.  Use methods and classes where appropriate, while breaking things into common implementations.

> Apart from the object creation, all other logics are move under seperate class.
> Hai @Ed Tanuos,
> Do we need to create a seperate main function and createsensor function for this gpio state via ipmb?
> please suggest your opinion on this.

There needs to be a signfican refactoring here.  There is way too much logic going into the config files (admittedly that was true with ipmbsensor before you made this change).  We need to abstract things cleanly;  The ideal declaration a user would make is a Type="my piece of hardware" in the config file, with the rest being dealt with by software.

This doesn't necessarily mean you need your own main, but it does mean that you need some reasonable abstractions, and reuse the methods that exist.


FWIW, the original comment was just telling you those two variables needed to go on their own lines (and be initialized).
Ack, the most of the configuration form the config files has been removed and just device name is specified in the config file and rest is done as code logic.
and these new properties are?  What do they do?
?  "host number" is not a common thing at this level.  This is taking "bus"

Generally "Done" or "This has been fixed" is what you use when things have been updated.  "ACK" generally means "I'm still working on this" and it's one of the reasons I thought this patch was still being worked.
Calling IPMB directly, while good for your own testing, doesn't prove anything about this review itself.
These aren't well known namespaces, and not where I would expect the pgood signals to be showing up.  As a general rule, "gpio" should not appear in dbus at all.

Apart from pgood there are multiple gpio's which are part of the twinlake, the main idea here is to make it available for all the gpio state, which are part of the twinlake host controller.
which is accessable via ipmb.
so this sensor  is not only just for monitoring pgood gpio, but to monitor state of any gpio which are only accessable via ipmb.

> the main idea here is to make it available for all the gpio state

We don't make gpio state directly available on dbus.  This has been discussed many times.  If you'd like to have another conversation about it, feel free to push a review to phosphor-dbus-interfaces.
Note done.  dbus interfaces still have "gpio? in them

Hai all,
Gentle remainder, Please review on this patch if possible.

Hai all,

Gentle remainder, Please review on this patch if possible.

There hasn't been any feedback on this commit in over a month now (Jan 10th).  I can tell there was some discussion to which Logananth replied, but it isn't clear if the reviewers were just not satisfied with the responses or they expected additional action to be taken.  

Can we please get some clear actionable feedback on next steps for this commit?  Is there anything fundamental about the approach here that we need to reexamine?
Sorry for missing the update. Change looks good to me.

I've left many multitudes of comments, many of which are coding style or code safety violations that I would expect most reviewers to be able to find.  There are plenty of patches that need reviewed, and maintainers don't have lots of time to spend on every single one.

There's obvious dbus-interface violations, not just in not following the existing interfaces, but in core principals like "don't put GPIO on dbus" that have been discussed many times.  Those kind of themes are things that just about any maintainer or developer can teach.

I'm sorry it's taking so long.  I really am.  Hopefully we can get things wrapped up soon.
looking on to wrapping up as soon as possible.

Current patchset STILL puts gpio on dbus.  Had this been corrected earlier, this patchset likely could've merged at least in part a long time ago, but when things are marked "done" that are very obviously not done, it holds up the review.  The latest series of pathsets still have problems that were mentioned many months ago.
This doesn't get used in any of the below interfaces, which I'm pretty sure means it doesn't belong in this file.
Please just inline these kind of definitions.  Until we get a lot of these that all use the same mechanisms (unlikely) it helps to have the code in one spot.
You've copied and pasted this definition.  Please don't.  Abstract to a common method where appropriate.
Please don't use globals for per-instance retries.  This will fail the minute you get more than one.
Just inline these things please.  They're only used in one place, so there's no need to declare them at this level
If init fails, shouldn't we be throwing an exception?   As is, this will just fail silently.

Please don't load these into per-instance variables, especially given that we only have one type here.  Write a routine that just switches on type (as you've done) and branches in the read routines (abstracting where appropriate).  I could maybe see caching this data if you were going to cache the whole IPMB command, so it didn't have to be regenerated each time, but considering it's trivial to construct (code wise) that doesn't seem advised.
Please don't capture by wildcard reference (yes, I know there are counter examples) explicitly capture your variables by either reference or value.

> Was this fixed?

this has been changed to this pointer and working on the review comments to make weak_from_this().
We need to be more specific here.  There are lots of dbus failures (all of them I think) where we should not be retrying.
working on this to make more specific.
As written, this is going to flood the logs.  I suspect this message can just be removed?
This logic is duplicated with lines 131-134.  Deduplicate please.
This is a functional failure.  We should not be retrying at all if the IPMB device gave us an OK response code, but the wrong length payload.
this happens only in case of slot cycle, the ipmb response may not populate completely at once. So that the length check function needs to be retrying for the worng length.

If the device returns the wrong length response when it's unplugged, then that's a bug further up or down the stack.  At this level, all ipmi responses should be correct.  I'm not quite sure why you would see an incorrect length response with a correct response status, but it's not something we should be considering here.

our understanding in this issue is more over related to the impb dbus service call rather than device response.
Any how we have resolved in the latest patch as we check for the valid ipmi response length before proceeding.
You're 5 levels deep into this code tree, and on your 3rd level of lambda, please abstract this code.
Please rename this to "mask" considering that's what it is.  Also, when converting an in to a bool, please be explicit and add > 0
this set_property call is done in 3 places in this routine.  Could they instead be done in one place, with a variable used to determine the value (as you've basically already done).
Please name this IpmbPowerMonitor.  The interface itself has nothing to do with GPIOs.

we are currently using only pgood gpio signal and other serveral gpio (pch,bios) can also be monitored via ipmb coammands if their configuration is added, this same sensor can be used to monitor other gpios too. so it's not specifi to only power monitor.
Given that each of those thing require different dbus interfaces, no they can't

Our idea is to have a single dbus interface with the property Gpiostate, all other such ipmb gpio's part of the host controller will have this property but with different dbus object paths to differentiate.
Right now we keeping it for pgood so keep it as IpmbGpioStateMonitor, but it can be extended for all other ipmb gpio's but only by adding EM config.

> Our idea is to have a single dbus interface with the property Gpiostate

This has been presented to the project and rejected many times.  Please search the mailing list, there was even a discussion about this recently.


> but it can be extended for all other ipmb gpio's but only by adding EM config.

No.  GPIO numbers should not go on dbus, regardless of whether they come from an EM config or not.
Understood, Right now implementation is only done to update pgood power state.
You're reading an entityId, then loading it into a variable called pgoodGpioByte.  I suspect this doesn't need configured at all, but from this, I'm not quite able to figure out what's going on.
Ack, instead of reading the entityid, configured from the code.
wanted to understand advantages of using inline variables here ..?
can we make this function as const ,being getter function ..?
are you treating above variable as constants ..?
yes, treating it as a constant, inline is not necessary for the variable's here so all can be changed.
query : wanted to know advantage of inline here .
inline is not necessary for the variables here, and changed in the following patches.

What if ChannelNames is not present in entity config ? 
Is there any default value assigned ?
the values couldn't be defined default her.
If this condition is satisfied, else part will not be used. You can prefer to use "continue" after line 591.
no need to use else here, if "continue" is used above.

Hai all,
Gentle remainder, Please review on this patch if possible.
no need for gpioInterface since for each gpio it is pushed into the Map
why inline here in cpp file?
nit: is this host name or controller name, i.e TwinlakeController?
yes, this method gets a single gpio name of the host controller(twinlake).

why the magic number 2 here?
what if pathName.size() is less than 2

some example path name 1_CPU_Good, 2_CPU_Good

As you can see pathName are prefixed with the host instance number, this logic is to remove thee host instance number and use only ipmbGpio name (so first two character are removed).
unlikely the ipmbGpio name are not less than two.

nit: From your example, I think this is "1_TwinlakeipmbGpiostate/1_CPU_Good". Right?
I think 1_TwinlakeipmbGpiostate canbe pathName or hostName and 1_CPU_Good is the gpioName
Need to remove all gpioInterface in gpioInterfaceMap
Why limit to Twinlake? Can it be IpmbGpioState or something more generic so other system can use it also
This is still the wrong path for this, and still mentions "gpio" on dbus.

Still not done.   /xyz/openbmc_project/ipmbgpio/1_TwinlakeipmbGpiostate/1_CPU_Good
is still present in your commit message, which has the word "gpio" in it.
In the latest patch, it will be resolved.
This is still the wrong path for this, and still mentions "gpio" on dbus.
Please make this a std::array so it doesn't need to be constructed at startup.
Why do this conversion?  Ideally we should be using a std::chrono type here, but I know that's not common, but there's no reason to be using another thing.

therefore, pollRate is float here so static_cast<int> is done as other sensors used.
suggestion, even changes need?
Please don't do manual dbus path manipulation.  We have sdbusplus::message::object_path.  Please use it.
Even using the sdbusplus::message::object_path type also wants to concatenate the variable to make the bus path, can you please help me in getting clarity on it?

I don't quite understand your question.

sdbusplus::message::object_path has operator/ and operator /= which allow for concatenating dbus paths.  Yes, for each individual portion of the path, string concat is fine, but when concatenating dbus path segments, use the aformentioned functions.
You do this lookup 3 times in 3 lines.  Please rearrange so you're only doing the lookup once.

missing range check.  Also, it's not clear why this is being done.  I suspect it's another case where it should be using sdbusplus::message::object_path, but it's hard to know based on the code.
You've hardcoded a path here.  This means that nothing with a different name will handle this function properly.
this twinlakIpmbgpioMap is platform specific to twinlake, for antother paltform additonal conditon check needs to be added along with their own gpio map.
memory safety issue.  Please look at the other examples of how we caputure using weak_from_this() to avoid lifetime issues.

Please don't put this much content in a lambda.  This has been mentioned about this function before.  This is actually 2 lambdas deep.  Break your functions up where necessary into the required callbacks to make the code readable.
Please don't rely on implicit bool conversion here.  == 0 would be fine, but ideally == <IPMI return code enum> would be better.

Since this code can be used by multiple types of hosts, it would be better to change the HostController name to be something more generic than TwinlakeHostController.
This is still searching on ipmbGpioState as a config file name.  We've discussed before, GPIO is not a high level type, the component you're adapting to is the twinlake controller, that is the type.
"Error reading ChannelNames from Json" would be a better phrasing for this error message.

The old code that existed was more correct.  We can always add more names that call the same code, as we have in many other places.  This has now changes to be much more generic, to the point that the config file isn't self-describing,

Thanks for making the previous changes.  I found one I missed with the namespace name which I think can be made more generic so it can be used on multiple platforms.  Otherwise, the changes are looking good.
Please ack the comments to indicate agreement or post responses so the reviewers know the status of this patchset even if any fixes to address them are not completed yet.  Thanks!

Sorry, missed this in previous review.  We should examine all twinlake definitions and replace them with generic options unless they are platform specific (and moved to platform specific code).  In this case, I think most of these functions are generic for any platform so changing the namespace from twinlake to something more generic is appropriate.
This is a platform specific config, this is better moved to EM config is best.

> This is a platform specific config, this is better moved to EM config is best.

Individual commands should not be moved to EM config.  That opens up too many possibilities for compatibility problems.  I have no problem with the twinlake-specific commands being here.  We do the same thing already for other oem-specific commands.
This needs a better name.  "HostController" could mean any one of a number of things.  This is targetting OpenBIC, correct?  Maybe OpenBIC might be an ok name?

No, the status can not be -ve value.

The value from ipmibridge is an 'int'.  It can, in fact, be negative.

https://github.com/openbmc/ipmbbridge/blob/0da15b5517b05685c5af70ff6ee5d67e523f47de/ipmbbridged.cpp#L140

Please don't use "-ve" as some shorthand.  This is maybe something that is used in EE circles but it is not generally accepted/understood in software circles.  I would not be surprised if the author didn't know what you were asking.
